div.p:
Will you be
so kind as to send
the bill for my
chronometer to
Wilbraham Taylor
1 Robert St.
Adelphi - Strand.

I find by a
letter from Sir
Roderick that he
thinks our
proposed arrangement
with Thornton
would be a
breach of faith
as he has drawn a part & moreover is a first
rate mettallurgist
& might get ยฃ400
at home.

I earnestly hope
that the matter
may be comfortably
arranged with
Baines. Mr
Wilson seemed
to suggest no
obstacle if (it
(an increase in
Baines' pay)
came in a regular
way through the
Foreign Office but
nothing can of
course be done
without your
full consent.
I did not go to
Mr Hammond
but have been
busy all day
leave taking - but
will tomorrow
after I have seen
you.

Are our instructions
drawn up? and
the agreement to
be signed? I don't
expect you to
answer these
questions but
I often forget
points when in
your presence
which are on
my mind when
quietly writing.
For this reason
too I mention
now that I got
a copy of a
decree of the
Portuguese Govt
which decides
that the valley
of the Zambesi
to which the
Portuguese crown lays
claim is henceforth
to be called

and it extends
to beyond Zumbo.
Had they named
the Longitude
it would have
coincided exactly
with what I
pointed out to
Mr Hammond for
Lord Clarendon's
information viz.
30ยบ E. of Greenwich
and the decree makes
all that we take
in free of duty.
That when they have
no custom house
nor even a village
at the entrance
(Luabo). I am &c
David Livingstone
